Posts.Content: sunflower45 wrote: I finished chemo and radiation about a year ago and today had a dental exam, the first in nearly a year.    The hygienist told me I had a lot of small cavities and others where the fillings had worn away.  She thought side effects from the chemo and radiation I had could be a cause of the problems.  Has anyone else had this happen to them?   Before the cancer   I had not had many dental problems. Dx 11/23/2008, ILC, 1cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: post chemo dental problems sunflower45 Moderators

Posts.Content: sunflower45 wrote: Hi     Does anyone have their chemo and radiation treatments at the same time?   I started chemo on Monday the 29th of December and got a call from the radiation department wanting to make an immediate appointment with me for an evaluation.   In spite of my protests,  she said a lot of women have chemo and radiation at the same time.   I cannot see doing that but wonder if it is common.  I had thought the radiation wouldn't start until the chemo was done in the spring. Dx 11/23/2008, ILC, 1cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: sunflower45 wrote: Hi    I'm scheduled to start chemo using a Picc line on December 29.  I was wondering since there are a lot of colds and flu going around this time of the year  if they still do the chemo treatment if you have a cold?  Dx 11/23/2008, ILC, 1cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: having a virus and chemo sunflower45 angie27

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2008 03:41PM sunflower45 wrote: I started physiotherapy as soon as my drain was out with a local guy experienced with mastectomy patients. (recommended by the hospital)   I've had only three sessions in two weeks and can pull loose sweatshirts over my head and otherwise move my arm around quite a bit but not as much as I could before the surgery.  I would suggest getting in touch with a therapist who knows how to treat mastectomy patients.  It wasn't that expensive either - $30.00 a treatment and I live in Canada.
Posts.Title: when can you wear clothes going on over head? rayhope sunflower45

Posts.Content: sunflower45 wrote: I had a lumpectomy yesterday but the surgeon was not checking any of the nodes.  I questioned him on this before the surgery but he said this was because the biopsy showed the tumor to be DCIS and it wasn't necessary.  He said that if there was any spread of the cancer it would show up in the margins after the surgery.  The biopsy was taken just at the edge of what felt to me to be a tumor that was at least 4.5 cm wide.  I've noticed that a lot of the ladies here have their nodes checked even with lumpectomies and I'm wondering if anyone has any comments on this. Dx 11/23/2008, ILC, 1cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: not checking nodes sunflower45 Jo_Ann_K
can a fast growing lump be benign? sunflower45 KC7

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2008 04:17AM sunflower45 wrote: Hi Braveone    I would strongly urge you to stick to the medical profession.   Cancer is not something for the naturalpathics to try to cure except to help with side effects from surgeries and drugs.   We had the wife of a very prominent person in our town insist on using natural means after being diagnosed with breast cancer.     She had a huge funeral just four years later.     Depending on what type of ductal carcinoma you have,   it can be 100% curable and very easy to treat.   All the best to you.
Posts.Title: Received the results yesterday BraveOne sunflower45

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2008 08:14PM sunflower45 wrote: I had a lumpectomy yesterday and as soon as I woke up they asked how bad the pain was.  It was bad so they immediately injected morphine into the thin tube they had in my arm.   After a few times of  this the pain was a lot better and it hasn't been  bad since.   Like bluedasher I felt a bit of throat soreness but had no tubes put down my throat when I was awake.   They will  make it as comfortable as they can for you.    The worst part is the anticipation.
Posts.Title: partial mastectomy/what to expect saraand45 ICanDoThis

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2008 05:20PM sunflower45 wrote: Hi    I'm scheduled to start December 29.  I had a Picc line inserted in my upper arm a week ago and asked if I could wait until after Christmas to start.   The line is a bit annoying but not painful and doesn't interfere with anything I want to do.   They don't do ports much where as I live as it takes surgical time that the docs can't get.    I'm scheduled for 6 cycles,  three weeks apart and then radiation afterwards.  I'm hoping the nausea and tiredness won't be any worse than what I had when I was pregnant.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2008 05:21PM sunflower45 wrote: If I were you,  I would do some serious research on the internet to see if the chemo is really necessary or if it might be overtreating.   I was told that I wouldn't have needed chemo if there had been no node involvement.
Posts.Title: Mom's chemo ajzjmsmom lisettemac

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2008 08:09AM sunflower45 wrote: The surgery was done on Monday,  the 17th.    The surgeon made a special  8 a.m. morning appointment for me.   However,  unfortunate for some others here,   my surgery took 4 hours when it was only scheduled for 2 1/2 and this meant at least one other person's surgery was postponed for that day.  I heard the nurse telling the individual when I was discharged around 3 p.m.    From what a nurse told me,  this sort of thing seems to be pretty common here and is especially hard on people who come from out of town or who have arranged time off work or babysitters.   My husband and I are retired so time isn't so restrictive for us.   I have been told by a woman friend  who is a retired nurse that it doesn't hurt to be a "squeaky wheel" around here but to be nice about it.
Posts.Title: surgery postponed sunflower45 BrendaD

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 11:19PM sunflower45 wrote: Thank you for all  your supportive messages.  It helped me feel better.   For next week's try I am going to bring my hooked rug,  my cross stitch,  and my knitting projects with me.  Just in case I have to wait a while ...... Maybe the hospital will get the message.    If I get sent home a second time without the surgery  I will declare myself an emergency patient the third time I go.   It seems they get priority bookings.   But I'm starting to wonder if this isn't akin to an emergency  anyway.  My biopsy for DCIS was in August,  a lumpectomy at the end of September,  the pathology report with the invasive cancer diagnosis in the middle of October and now this.   The cancer could be going anywhere by now, especially since all the specs were listed at grade 3.    I do agree with whippetmom,  however.   I wouldn't want a tired out surgeon working on me.
Posts.Title: surgery postponed sunflower45 BrendaD

Posts.Content: sunflower45 wrote: How many of you have geared yourselves up physically and mentally for a mastectomy,  fasted, and gone to the hospital and waited around for five hours or more only to be told there were emergencies and/ or the guy ahead of you took 3 hours instead of the planned one hour.   You are then told your surgery has been postponed to another day a week down the road.   How did you feel?   It's hard enough to get ready for surgery you don't want in the first place but feel you have no choice.   It happened to me yesterday and my poor husband had to put up with my tears and bad mood last night.   I felt the hospital should have a separate operating room for emergencies and not take up time and space meant for scheduled day surgeries. Dx 11/23/2008, ILC, 1cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: surgery postponed sunflower45 BrendaD

Posts.Content: sunflower45 wrote: I had a mammogram just over a year ago and three weeks ago felt a large hard mass in my left breast two days before we were scheduled to leave on a trip.  As soon as I got home I called my family doctor and she saw me two days later,  felt the lump and got me in for a mammogram a day and a half later,  which was last Friday,  July 25.    I'm hoping it will be benign but I'm wondering if it takes so long for a tumor to grow  (I've been seeing 6-8 years on this website),  shouldn't the lump have shown up on last year's mammogram?     I'm feeling so scared I almost don't want to answer the phone next week.    I'm 63.                        Sunflower45 Dx 11/23/2008, ILC, 1cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: can a fast growing lump be benign? sunflower45 KC7

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2008 08:46AM sunflower45 wrote: Just an update.   I had another mammogram yesterday and then went to talk to my primary care doctor.   She said the lump is about the size of a golf ball and is growing fast.  She also said she strongly suspects it is cancer.   She has made an appointment for me with a surgeon at the end of August and is trying to get an appointment for a biopsy before that if she can.    I live in Northern Ontario and there is a shortage of doctors here plus some are on vacation.  I am very scared but feel fortunate that my husband has been so supportive.  He goes with me to all the appointments even though it mean sitting around for long periods of time.   It's a pretty scary time for him also.
Posts.Title: can a fast growing lump be benign? sunflower45 KC7

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 04:21PM sunflower45 wrote: I had a lumpectomy three weeks ago and I think it might depend on the size of the lump and how old you are.  I am 63 and my lump was 7cm x 8.5 cm x 4cm.  I didn't feel well for a few days and got really tired for a couple of weeks after.   The pain was bad only right after the surgery and they gave me morphine.   They will likely give you tylenol 3 with codeine and also a stool softener.   Be sure to take the stool softener.   Morphine and codeine are really constipating.     Best wishes for a favorable pathology report!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy - What to expect? EleanorJ koshka1
